aws::graph::propositions: # Pitts S-12 Aircraft Fuel Planning and Engine Failure Incident
The pilot reported it felt like either fuel was completely shut off or ignition was totally lost.
Jim Kimball Enterprises specializes in antique aircraft restoration.
Jim Kimball Enterprises specializes in replica aircraft design and construction.
Jim Kimball Enterprises specializes in kit aircraft component manufacture.
Jim Kimball Enterprises built the Pitts S-12 aircraft involved in the incident.
The pilot's flight was 3.5 hours long.
The 3.5-hour flight was about an hour longer than others planned for with that engine and fuel capacity.
The main fuel tank had a capacity of 32 gallons.
The main fuel tank was plumbed directly to the 4-gallon header tank.
The pilot used a climb fuel burn rate of 36 gallons per hour in flight planning.
The pilot used a cruise fuel burn rate of 12 gallons per hour in flight planning.
The pilot calculated total fuel burn was 44.8 gallons.
The pilot calculated total flight time was 3 hours and 25 minutes.
NTSB calculations used the pilot's waypoints and times.
NTSB calculations used POH-provided fuel burn rates of 46 gallons per hour for climb.
NTSB calculations used POH-provided fuel burn rates of 14 gallons per hour for economy cruise.
NTSB calculations resulted in a total fuel consumption of 51.3 gallons.
Calculations using the normal cruise fuel burn rate of 16 gallons per hour resulted in a total fuel burn of 58.3 gallons for the trip.
The total fuel burn of 58.3 gallons was 5.3 gallons more than the maximum usable fuel quantity.
The factual report for this investigation was posted to the NTSB web site in late October 2015.
The pilot sent the NTSB investigator an email on November 16, 2015.
The pilot stated he had read the report.
The pilot noted that the report's POH fuel burn citations were different than the values from a power setting chart he had used for flight planning.
The pilot stated that the power setting chart he used was for the fuel-injected version of the engine.

text:
For what its worth it felt like either fuel was completely shut off or ignition was totally lost."

## Fuel Planning Information

According to a representative of Jim Kimball Enterprises, which according to its website is a company that "specializes in antique aircraft restoration, replica aircraft design and construction, and kit aircraft component manufacture," including the Pitts S-12, and which was the company that built the airplane, the pilot's 3.5 hour flight was "about an hour longer than others planned for with that engine and fuel capacity."

The representative also stated that the main fuel tank had a capacity of 32 gallons, and was plumbed directly to the 4-gallon header tank.

Evaluation of the pilot-provided flight planning information revealed that the pilot used a climb fuel burn rate of 36 gph, and a cruise fuel burn rate of 12gph. His total calculated fuel burn was 44.8 gallons, over a total flight time of 3 hours and 25 minutes. NTSB calculations that used the pilot's waypoints and times, but used POH-provided fuel burn rates of 46 gph for climb and 14 gph for economy cruise resulted in a total fuel consumption of 51.3 gallons. Calculations that used the normal cruise fuel burn rate of 16 gph resulted in a total fuel burn of 58.3 gallons for the trip, which was 5.3 gallons more than the maximum usable fuel quantity.

## Pilot's November 16, 2015, Input and Investigation Follow-up

The factual report for this investigation was posted to the NTSB web site in late October 2015. On November 16, 2015, the pilot sent the NTSB investigator an email stating that he had read the report and noted that the report's POH fuel burn citations were different than the values from a power setting chart that he had used for his flight planning. In further email communications, the pilot stated that the power setting chart he used was for the fuel-injected version of the engine, and "as the POH was based on a
